comments: Needed in order to define what is a "well defined" ECore model.
*** Bug 76248 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

A required, non-unsettable, primitive-typed attribute should be considered ill-
defined.

Currently, if a required, primitive-typed (e.g. EBoolean) attribute is not 
unsettable, it will fail validation until its value is changed to something 
other than its default (e.g. true).

When creating an EMF model through UML and then transforming to the ecore model
some names from he model environment turn over to packages name with a captial
letter. The person creating the model wasn't aware that it turns out through the
process to a JAVA package name. So what I would like to be supported is that
during the generation of the JAVA code and the packages a warning would be
issued to indicate that the package name does not comply to JAVA naming
conventions and could lead therefore to malfunctions of further tooling working
with the generated code. Maybe this can be done. It would really save a lot of
time for some people running into the same problem which do not think in the
first place of JAVA nameing conventions because they work during the modeling in
another scope where maybe other naming conventions do apply. (Note this is my
first reported bug, and the second try to enter it, so hopefully it is there
only once if, not beginners problem, sorry for that.)
[plan pri=3 est=4w/]

*** Bug 108384 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Hi, Ed Merks pointed me here to report an issue:

Declaring a EDataType within an ecore model with InstanceClassName set to a
class which is available within a eclipse project (via plugin dependency or
whatever) lets the validation fail with a ClassNotFoundException (see the
stacktrace below).

A concrete example:
I've declared an EDatatype with
InstanceClassName=org.eclipse.target.ITargetResource.
The corresponding plugin dependency is in the plugins MANIFEST.MF. On validation
I get a java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.eclipse.target.ITargetResource.

regards,
Marcel

The stacktrace:

==== Ed Merks response ===
 Marcel,

When we deal with https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=75933 we'll have
to consider this issue.  It looks like the validation will try to instantiate
the instance class in a context where that class might not be visible/loadable;
that shouldn't make the model appear invalid or cause other problems.  It would
be great if you add a comment to that bugzilla.  Perhaps we should change this
method in EClassifierImpl to return null rather than throw a wrapped exception.:

      public Class getInstanceClass()
      {
        if (instanceClass == null && (instanceClassName != null ||
generatedInstanceClassName != null))
        {
          try
          {
            setInstanceClassGen(getClassForName(getInstanceClassName()));
          }
          catch (ClassNotFoundException e)
          {
            Class primitiveClass = getPrimitiveOrArrayClass();
            if (primitiveClass != null)
              setInstanceClassGen(primitiveClass);
            else
              throw new WrappedException(e);
          }
        }
        return getInstanceClassGen();
      }
*** Bug 125611 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I know Java conventions but they are not mandatory (what about aother languages conventions? and converting between them?)

I beleive that there should be a possibility to create fragments of ECore models with "invalid" markup for their include/link/reutilization.

For, example in .NET there are custom controls to be included/reused in webpages. They do not contain root markup tags since they are to be included in another markup (and it is not an error)

Any way, EMF should be more user-/developer-friendly (and only researcher-friendly)


Guennadi Vanine
This item does not look to be containable in the time remaining.

Created an attachment (id=56150)
A complete set of patches for all the constraints I could think of.

This is quite complete and includes constraints for the new generics support. Generic bound checking as the one thing that's not so solid yet.  The JUnit test plugin has complete tests to cover all the cases and has a Bad.ecore with examples of all the constraint violations that are detected.

Created an attachment (id=56176)
Many changes to support generic bound checking better

There is an Example.ecore model showing the types of bound checking that is being done.  The idea being that the generated code for this model should have exactly and only the errors reported in the Ecore model itself. This turned up what appear to be a few problems in the Eclipse compiler reporting bogus errors:
  https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=169049

Part of the changes here include removing the ETypeParameter.eGenericTypes reference (the inverse of EGenericType.eTypeParameter). The inverse is still maintained internally, but not as a notifying feature.  This allows one to copy things containing references to type parameters without losing them and avoids problems in the future where one might like to construct a resolved generic type including making references to ETypeParameters without having to worry about the inverse holding a reference forever.

The code is committed to CVS.  I believe it will diagnose all the problems reported in the duplicates before the generator tries to generate any code.  If there's anything we've missed, please bring them to our attention.  Note that changes in the runtime include making it tolerant of circular inheritance (no stack overflow), make EAttribute.eAttributeType and EReference.eReferenceType avoid class cast exceptions when the type is set incorrectly, and making EClassifier.instanceClass return null instead of throwing an exception when the instance class name can't be resolved to a class.

3.0M4 After using GMF's ecore_diagram editor to delete a child class, a dangling containment reference is left behind (a GMF bug) - EReference.eType is null.

Attempting to genModel this gets
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.emf.codegen.ecore.genmodel.impl.GenTypedElementImpl.getTypeGenPackage(GenTypedElementImpl.java:80)
	at org.eclipse.emf.codegen.ecore.genmodel.impl.GenPackageImpl$DependencyHelper.<init>(GenPackageImpl.java:2023)

	at org.eclipse.ui.actions.WorkspaceModifyOperation$1.run(WorkspaceModifyOperation.java:101)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run(Workspace.java:1743)
	at org.eclipse.ui.actions.WorkspaceModifyOperation.run(WorkspaceModifyOperation.java:113)
	at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:113)
 which appears in the Error Log but which provokes no other GUI interaction to explain the problem.

Upgrading org.eclipse.emf.codegen.ecore and org.eclipse.emf.ecore from CVS HEAD does not appear to make any difference other than minor line number changes.

Edward,

We've changed the validation method of the GenModel editor to also invoke the EcoreValidator.  This would catch this problem.  Thx for reporting the issue.
